book.name: Comparing IDEA, Rehab Act, and ADAAA

chapter.title: Comparing IDEA, Rehab Act, and ADAAA
chapter.content:
Comparing IDEA, Rehab Act, and ADAAA

This diagram summarizes important aspects of IDEA, the Rehab Act, and the ADAAA.

Looking at this diagram, we can see that all three of these laws share a common purpose: to protect the rights of people with disabilities by prohibiting discrimination on the basis of disability.

chapter.title: Distinctive elements of IDEA
chapter.content:
Distinctive elements of IDEA

We can see that IDEA is distinctive because:

  • it is limited to students who are participating in special education services in a K-12 setting;
  • once identified, a student is entitled to special education and related services;
  • once students exit school, the act no longer applies to their education;
  • once a student is referred, the school system is responsible for the identification and diagnostic process; and
  • students who graduate or exit as part of the IEP process should have an SOP document, which can be useful for adult service providers.

chapter.title: Distinctive elements of the Rehab Act
chapter.content:
Distinctive elements of the Rehab Act

The Rehab Act is distinctive due to:

  • the provision of limited funding for services, with no guarantee of services as they are provided on a competitive system, based on need; and
  • non-discrimination is limited to employment and services provided by entities under federal contract or receiving federal funding – including educational institutions.

chapter.title: Distinctive elements of the ADAAA
chapter.content:
Distinctive elements of the ADAAA

The ADAAA is distinctive because it extends non-discrimination protections to a broad range of American society, not limited by federal funding or K-12 school settings.

In addition, note that it provides no funding for services relative to its provisions.

chapter.title: IDEA and Rehab Act both provide funds for services
chapter.content:
IDEA and Rehab Act both provide funds for services

Note that both the IDEA and the Rehab Act provide funds for services, but as we have noted, under IDEA, once an individual is diagnosed, services are provided, whereas under the Rehab Act, individuals with LD may find services difficult to access.

chapter.title: Provisions provided by both ADAAA and Rehab Act
chapter.content:
Provisions provided by both ADAAA and Rehab Act

However, the ADAAA and the Rehab Act both

  • apply to individuals of any age;
  • require an individual to disclose his or her disability in order to gain benefits from the laws; and
  • employers and agencies to provide  “reasonable accommodations.”

In the next activity, we will ask you to reflect on what you have learned about the Rehab Act and the ADAAA and consider the implications of these two laws for the adult learners you serve.

chapter.title: Benefits of the Rehab Act and ADAAA to adults with LD
chapter.content:
Benefits of the Rehab Act and ADAAA to adults with LD

While other answers may apply, the most significant benefits of the Rehab Act and the ADAAA to individuals with disabilities are:

  • Individuals with disabilities cannot be denied access to educational services because of their disabilities.
  • Individuals with disabilities have a right to reasonable accommodations on the job, in education, and in almost all adult life situations.

Take a moment to compare your reflections with those listed.

chapter.title: Limitations of the Rehab Act and ADAAA for adults with LD
chapter.content:
Limitations of the Rehab Act and ADAAA for adults with LD

While other answers may apply, the most significant limitations of the Rehab Act and the ADAAA to individuals with LD wishing to access accommodation are:

  • He or she will have to advocate for accommodations by disclosing the disability.
  • The individual will also have to provide their own documentation of the disability. This means the individual must have a good understanding of his or her disability and be comfortable identifying what he or she needs to be successful.
  • Access to funding for diagnosis or services is limited and individuals with learning disabilities are likely to have difficulties accessing funded services due to the ‘order of selection’ process. This may make it difficult to self-advocate for accommodations.

Please take a moment to compare your answers with those listed.

While addressing our first guiding question: “Which federal laws affect adults with LD?” we noted that both the Rehab Act and ADAAA require self-disclosure in order to access reasonable accommodations. This leads us to our next guiding question.
